content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Gas Price Relief Act," temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes by setting the tax rates to zero during the suspension period. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends various fuel taxes, including those on diesel fuel, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, alcohol fuels, gasoline, kerosene, and fuels used in trains, motorboats, and aviation. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends certain fuel taxes, excluding taxes on fuel used in trains, motorboats, and aviation, during a defined "suspension period" based on gasoline prices. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends certain fuel taxes based on gasoline prices, with an effective date upon enactment. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends certain fuel taxes based on gasoline prices, with an effective date upon enactment. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN REFINERIES. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends fuel taxes based on gasoline prices. Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code, relating to expensing certain refineries, is repealed. Technical amendments are made to various sections of the Code. Transfer of equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund is mentioned. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends fuel taxes based on gasoline prices and repeals section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code. Equivalent tax liability is transferred to the Highway Trust Fund from the general fund of the Treasury. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends fuel taxes and transfers equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund from the general fund of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury estimates tax liabilities and makes transfers based on a schedule. Adjustments are made for prior estimates. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Floor stock refunds are provided for in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If a tax has been imposed on a liquid before the enactment of this Act and the liquid is held by a dealer for sale without being used, the taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for the excess tax paid. Claims for refunds must be filed within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. The taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment of the Act. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the Act, and certain conditions apply for refunds. No credit or refund allowed for liquid in retail stocks held at the place intended for retail sale. Definitions of "dealer" and "held by a dealer" follow section 6412 of the Code, including a producer. Rules similar to section 6412 apply for this section. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 over the tax already paid. Liability and payment methods are outlined, with the tax due within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held by a person, to be paid within 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. Definitions for "held by a person," "taxable liquid," and "floor stocks tax date" are provided for clarity. The tax imposed on taxable liquid by subsection (a) does not apply to liquid held exclusively for exempt uses or fuel held in a vehicle tank. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or delegate. Exception for Exempt Uses: The tax does not apply to liquid held for specific uses if a credit or refund is allowable. No tax on liquid in vehicle tanks. No tax on liquid held on floor stocks tax date if under 2,000 gallons. On the floor stocks tax date, a person is exempt from the tax if the liquid held does not exceed 2,000 gallons. Fuel exempt from tax under certain subsections is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes, with the definition of a controlled group based on ownership percentages. The floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) are subject to all provisions of law, including penalties, applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the Code. Principles similar to those for incorporated persons apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly. Reports will be submitted to Congress and made available to the public online. SEC. 7. COMMISSION ON GAS PRICE RELIEF. Establishment of a Commission on Gas Price Relief by the Speaker of the House of Representatives within three months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House within a year. Membership includes 9 Members, with the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means as an ex officio member. The Commission on Gas Price Relief, established by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, will have 9 Members including the Chairmen of the Committee on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce. Membership also includes members appointed by the Chairmen and the Speaker, with specific party affiliations requirements.
